thread.title: CNU women, unbeaten min defeat St. Mary's in soccer
thread.title_full: CNU women, unbeaten min defeat St. Mary's in soccer

title: CNU women, unbeaten min defeat St. Mary's in soccer
text:
CNU women, unbeaten min defeat St. Mary's in soccer Daily Press 
COLLEGES: 
Women’s soccer: 
Christopher Newport (9-3-1) won 2-0 Wednesday at St. Mary’s (Md.), pulling even with the Seahawks (6-6) in the Capital Athletic Conference at 4-1. The Captains won their fourth game in a row. 
Alexis Haycraft netted a penalty kick in the 78th minute, and Lindsay Mondloch bent in a corner kick in the 82nd. Carly Maglio made three saves for a shutout. 
Men’s soccer: 
Ryan Balfour and Harry Nodwell scored second-half goals as Christopher Newport, ranked 13th in Division III, won 2-1 at St. Mary’s (Md.). 
The Captains (10-0-4, 3-0-2 CAC) improved to 4-0-2 this season in games in which they trailed. Freshman goalkeeper Zach Pedini gained the win in his first collegiate start.. 
Field hockey: 
Anna Dessoye chipped in a second-half goal, lifting No. 7 Maryland to a 1-0 victory at No. 11 Old Dominion. The Terrapins (12-3) have won 10 games in a row. ODU (8-4) incurred its first shutout defeat. 
With 15:43 left in the game, Dessoye scored unassisted off a penalty corner. She lifted the ball over goalkeeper Kealsie Robles. ODU, which was outshot 11-4, didn’t get its first shot on goal until there were about 10 minutes remaining. 
Women’s golf: 
ODU’s Rachel Walker was named the Conference USA Golfer of the Week after tying for third place at the Pinehurst Challenge in North Carolina. The junior from Dumfries, Scotland, shot a career-best 6-under-par 210 (71-71-68). 
HOCKEY: 
The ECHL’s Norfolk Admirals, who open their regular season Friday at Scope Arena, traded left winger Jordan Kremyr to the Tulsa Oilers in exchange for forward Tom Mele. 
Mele, 29, will come to Norfolk with three seasons of ECHL experience. The New Yorker started his pro career during the Central Hockey League playoffs, when he joined the Fort Wayne Komets in 2010 and went on the following year to help them capture the league's President's Cup. 
Kremyr, 29, has skated in 191 games in the ECHL and 16 in the AHL after finishing four seasons at Providence College.
